M.G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: The Plaintiff requests the Court modify the existing custody order to grant primary physical custody to her, with visitation rights to the Defendant as determined by the Court.

Franco v. Franco, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 37 (1.raw_text: Franco v. Franco, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 37 (1977)
Franco v. Franco, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 37 (1.proposition: Subsequent to the entry of the original custody order, a material change in circumstances has occurred.
Franco v. Franco, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 37 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion in Franco v. Franco is a criminal case concerning the sufficiency of circumstantial evidence to support a conviction for assault with intent to rob. It does not involve family law, custody orders, or standards for modifying custody based on a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition that a material change in circumstances occurred after entry of an original custody order.
Franco v. Franco, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 37 (1.relevant_excerpt: The sole question raised by a motion for a directed verdict is whether on this evidence and reasonable inferences therefrom the jury could find beyond a reasonable doubt that the car found on Mt. Vernon Street was the same one used in the attempted robbery and that the defendant had been the operator of that vehicle.

Weedon v. Weedon, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 645.proposition: The Plaintiff respectfully asks the Court to consider the best interests of the child in granting the requested modification.

Stokes v. Stokes, 53 Mass. App. Ct. 767.raw_text: Stokes v. Stokes, 53 Mass. App. Ct. 767 (2002)
Stokes v. Stokes, 53 Mass. App. Ct. 767.proposition: The Defendant's condition has led to multiple falls at home, rendering him unable to be alone with the child in situations requiring quick physical response.
Stokes v. Stokes, 53 Mass. App. Ct. 767.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a post-divorce contempt action about a ‘take no action’ confidentiality/jeopardy clause in a separation agreement. It does not involve any facts about a defendant’s medical or physical condition, falls at home, child care, or inability to respond quickly to a child. The proposition about the defendant’s condition and falls is wholly unrelated to the legal and factual issues in this case, so this citation does not support that proposition.
Stokes v. Stokes, 53 Mass. App. Ct. 767.relevant_excerpt: “Following protracted and fractious divorce proceedings, Lawrence and Gloria Sax reached an agreement later incorporated into a judgment ending their forty-year marriage. Lasting peace, however, proved elusive. Lawrence soon filed a complaint for contempt alleging that Gloria had violated a provision of the agreement prohibiting her from disclosing what she claimed were Lawrence’s pre-agreement financial misdeeds.”

Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 51.raw_text: Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 512 (1987)
Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 51.proposition: It is in the best interests of the child that she primarily resides with the Plaintiff, with appropriate visitation for the Defendant.
Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 51.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is not Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 512 (1987), but a criminal case involving John Fidler and multiple stabbings. It concerns assault, joint venture liability, evidentiary issues, and jury instructions on armed assault with intent to murder, not child custody or best interests of a child. Therefore, it does not address, much less support, a proposition about the child’s best interests or residential custody between plaintiff and defendant.
Grubert v. Grubert, 23 Mass. App. Ct. 51.relevant_excerpt: Following is an account of the case as the jury could see it. Lisa Buccieri left her home in West Roxbury about 9:30 p.m., July 14, and drove to Roslindale to pick up her friends Julie Greene and Gail Crosby... For the stabbings of Julie Greene, John Hennessy, and Stephen Celata... Fidler was convicted of the assault and battery by means of a dangerous weapon...

Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2.raw_text: Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2016)
Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2.proposition: The proposed modification of custody is necessary to ensure the safety, stability, and well-being of the minor child, Sophia Smith, given the Defendant's health condition and the limitations it imposes on his ability to care for the child.
Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2.case_name: Fletcher Fixed Income Alpha Fund, Ltd. v. Grant Thornton LLP
Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is not Lynch v. Lynch at all but a commercial case involving Fletcher Fixed Income Alpha Fund and issues of personal jurisdiction and proximate cause in an accounting malpractice context. It does not involve custody, child welfare, parental health conditions, or any family-law standards for modifying custody orders. Therefore, it cannot be authority for a proposition about modifying custody to protect a child’s safety and well‑being given a parent’s health limitations.
Lynch v. Lynch, 89 Mass. App. Ct. 721 (2.relevant_excerpt: “MBTARF brought claims against SS&C for negligent misrepresentation, aiding and abetting fraud, and violation of G. L. c. 93A, § 11… Causation is a necessary element of the plaintiff’s claims against SS&C… Given the allegations indicating that Alpha was insolvent when SS&C took over as fund administrator, the judge properly relied on lack of proximate cause as a basis for dismissal.”

Kramer v. Kramer, 480 Mass. 338 (2015).proposition: On March 12, 2019, the Bristol County Probate and Family Court entered an Order establishing a 50/50 physical custody arrangement for the parties' minor child, Sophia Smith, with one week on and one week off schedule.
Kramer v. Kramer, 480 Mass. 338 (2015).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a 2019 Bristol County Probate and Family Court order establishing a 50/50 physical custody schedule for a child named Sophia Smith. Kramer v. Kramer is a 2015 Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court criminal case about a juvenile homicide defendant and issues of expert funding, premeditation, and public trial rights; it does not involve family law, custody, Bristol County Probate and Family Court, or any 2019 order. Therefore, this opinion does not support the claimed custody proposition.

Sorenson, 106 Mass. 125 (201.proposition: Despite medical advice indicating limitations in caring for the child, the Defendant insists on maintaining the current 50/50 custody arrangement and at times requires the minor child to assist in tasks beyond her age-appropriate responsibilities, such as helping with mobility and care.
Sorenson v. Sorenson, 106 Mass. 125 (201.support_reasoning: The opinion is a 19th‑century Massachusetts contract/partnership dispute concerning the validity of a sale of goods, promissory notes, and the effect of a prior judgment. It does not involve family law, custody arrangements, parental fitness, medical limitations on caregiving, or age‑appropriate responsibilities of a child. The cited proposition about a defendant insisting on 50/50 custody despite medical advice is entirely unrelated to the legal and factual issues in this case, so the case does not support that proposition.
Sorenson v. Sorenson, 106 Mass. 125 (201.relevant_excerpt: The plaintiff’s claim in this action is for goods sold (including also the good will of the former firm) to both defendants for $1600, on October 23, 1865, upon the dissolution of that firm... And it appeared that a suit had been brought upon the above described note... The judge refused so to rule, and as we think was right in so doing.
